subject: Cybersecurity
title: Credential Stuffing: Reusing Your Passwords Against You
description: A micro-lesson that makes Credential Stuffing: Reusing Your Passwords Against You usable.

hook.text: Hackers don't need to crack your password. They just try the one you used on another site that was already breached.

buildup.text: Credential stuffing uses leaked username/password pairs from one breach to log into accounts on other services.

discovery.text: Since 65% of people reuse passwords, a breach on one site compromises accounts on dozens of others.

twist.text: Automated tools test millions of stolen credentials per hour across hundreds of websites simultaneously.

climax.text: Credential stuffing is why unique passwords matter. One reused password means one breach compromises everything.

punchline.text: Your Netflix password got hacked. Now they're in your bank.

quiz.question: What makes credential stuffing attacks possible?
options: People reusing the same passwords across multiple services
